<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 186, 171, 201]]<|/det|>
# PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 206, 332, 222]]<|/det|>
Paper 1 Multiple Choice (Core)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[782, 186, 907, 200]]<|/det|>
0625/13  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[782, 207, 907, 222]]<|/det|>
May/June 2017  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[814, 228, 907, 242]]<|/det|>
45 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 248, 590, 291]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: Multiple Choice Answer Sheet Soft clean eraser Soft pencil (type B or HB recommended)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 311, 388, 328]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 342, 237, 357]]<|/det|>
Write in soft pencil.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 357, 504, 372]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 372, 892, 401]]<|/det|>
Write your name, Centre number and candidate number on the Answer Sheet in the spaces provided unless this has been done for you.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 400, 383, 415]]<|/det|>
DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 429, 892, 459]]<|/det|>
There are forty questions on this paper. Answer all questions. For each question there are four possible answers A, B, C and D.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 459, 890, 475]]<|/det|>
Choose the one you consider correct and record your choice in soft pencil on the separate Answer Sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 488, 556, 504]]<|/det|>
Read the instructions on the Answer Sheet very carefully.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 517, 764, 533]]<|/det|>
Each correct answer will score one mark. A mark will not be deducted for a wrong answer.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 533, 467, 548]]<|/det|>
Any rough working should be done in this booklet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 549, 359, 564]]<|/det|>
Electronic calculators may be used.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 564, 630, 579]]<|/det|>
Take the weight of \(1.0\mathrm{kg}\) to be \(10\mathrm{N}\) (acceleration of free fall \(= 10\mathrm{m / s}^2\) ).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 477, 88]]<|/det|>
A candle burns evenly. It is used as a timer.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 101, 561, 119]]<|/det|>
The candle is lit and burns down to point X in 2 hours.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 131, 759, 149]]<|/det|>
To which labelled point does the candle burn down after a further 30 minutes?

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[346, 159, 645, 485]]<|/det|>

<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 510, 920, 545]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 556, 920, 590]]<|/det|>
Three students measure the time as 17.2 s. Another student measures it as 16.9 s, and the fifth student measures it as 17.0 s.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 602, 490, 619]]<|/det|>
What is the average period of the pendulum?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[473, 630, 539, 648]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 602, 104, 621]]<|/det|>
<label>11</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 602, 801, 621]]<|/det|>
A student uses her thumb to push in a drawing pin (thumb tack) into a notice board.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 632, 630, 650]]<|/det|>
The pin goes into the board but does not penetrate her thumb.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 662, 376, 680]]<|/det|>
Which statement explains this?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 691, 133, 708]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 691, 920, 724]]<|/det|>
The force exerted by the pin on her thumb is greater than the force exerted on the notice board.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 733, 131, 751]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 733, 920, 765]]<|/det|>
The force exerted by the pin on the notice board is greater than the force exerted on her thumb.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 774, 133, 792]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 774, 860, 791]]<|/det|>
The pressure of the pin on her thumb is greater than the pressure on the notice board.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 801, 133, 819]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 801, 860, 819]]<|/det|>
The pressure of the pin on the notice board is greater than the pressure on her thumb.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 106, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>12</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 890, 91]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 102, 539, 120]]<|/det|>
What pressure does the cube exert on the ground?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 129, 138, 147]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 129, 240, 147]]<|/det|>
\(480 \text{kg} /\text{m}^3\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[281, 129, 303, 147]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[312, 129, 411, 147]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[475, 129, 537, 147]]<|/det|>
\(4800 \text{N} /\text{m}^2\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[615, 129, 636, 147]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[650, 129, 747, 147]]<|/det|>

<label>13</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 173, 851, 192]]<|/det|>
The diagram represents molecules of a gas inside a closed container of constant volume.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[406, 203, 588, 304]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 316, 719, 335]]<|/det|>
What happens to the molecules of the gas when the container is heated?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 344, 134, 363]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 344, 267, 363]]<|/det|>
They expand.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 371, 131, 390]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 371, 361, 390]]<|/det|>
They get closer together.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 397, 131, 416]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 397, 507, 416]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 424, 133, 443]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 424, 304, 443]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 468, 107, 486]]<|/det|>
<label>14</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 467, 836, 486]]<|/det|>
Brownian motion is observed when using a microscope to look at smoke particles in air.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 497, 561, 515]]<|/det|>
What causes the smoke particles to move at random?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 526, 133, 544]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 526, 487, 544]]<|/det|>
Smoke particles are hit by air molecules.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 553, 131, 571]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 553, 650, 571]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 580, 131, 598]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 580, 700, 598]]<|/det|>
Smoke particles have different weights and fall at different speeds.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 606, 131, 625]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 606, 527, 625]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 650, 107, 668]]<|/det|>
<label>15</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 650, 761, 668]]<|/det|>
The temperature of a bridge rises from \(5^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\) on a cold night to \(25^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\) at midday.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 680, 358, 697]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 707, 131, 725]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 707, 316, 725]]<|/det|>
It becomes heavier.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 734, 131, 752]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 734, 354, 752]]<|/det|>
It becomes more dense.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 761, 131, 780]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 761, 320, 780]]<|/det|>
Its length increases.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 788, 133, 806]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 788, 312, 805]]<|/det|>
Its mass increases.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 107, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>16</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 71, 668, 90]]<|/det|>
Equal masses of two different liquids are put into identical beakers.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 101, 856, 120]]<|/det|>
Liquid 1 is heated for 100 s and liquid 2 is heated for 200 s by heaters of the same power.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 131, 494, 149]]<|/det|>
Each liquid has the same rise in temperature.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[161, 156, 833, 425]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 438, 349, 456]]<|/det|>
Which statement is correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 466, 134, 484]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 466, 591, 485]]<|/det|>
Each beaker of liquid has the same thermal capacity.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 494, 134, 512]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 494, 551, 512]]<|/det|>
Each beaker of liquid receives the same energy.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 521, 133, 539]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 520, 515, 539]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 547, 134, 565]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 546, 771, 565]]<|/det|>
The thermal capacity of liquid 1 is less than the thermal capacity of liquid 2.

The solid changes into a liquid and then into a gas. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 116, 658, 134]]<|/det|> The graph shows how the temperature of the substance changes. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[106, 144, 890, 415]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 429, 710, 448]]<|/det|> What is the melting point and what is the boiling point of the substance? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 459, 443, 604]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 257, 106, 275]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 257, 626, 275]]<|/det|> In which way are a bar magnet and an electromagnet similar? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 285, 134, 303]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 285, 757, 303]]<|/det|> A bar magnet and an electromagnet are always magnetised when stored. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 312, 134, 330]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 312, 920, 344]]<|/det|> A bar magnet and an electromagnet can both be used to separate magnetic and non-magnetic materials. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 352, 134, 370]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 352, 777, 370]]<|/det|> A bar magnet can be made of steel and an electromagnet uses a steel core. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 378, 134, 396]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 378, 881, 396]]<|/det|> The magnetic field strength of a bar magnet and of an electromagnet can both be varied. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 422, 106, 441]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 422, 477, 440]]<|/det|> Which material is a conductor of electricity? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 451, 141, 469]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 451, 201, 469]]<|/det|> brass <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 478, 138, 496]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 478, 200, 496]]<|/det|> glass <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 504, 138, 523]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 504, 210, 521]]<|/det|> plastic <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 530, 141, 548]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 530, 200, 548]]<|/det|> wood

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 106, 91]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 796, 92]]<|/det|> The diagram shows a circuit containing two resistors of resistance \(1.0 \Omega\) and \(2.0 \Omega\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 103, 707, 122]]<|/det|> A voltmeter is connected across the \(1.0 \Omega\) resistor by connecting P to X. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 134, 425, 152]]<|/det|> The reading on the voltmeter is \(6.0 \text{V}\). <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[354, 160, 640, 320]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 330, 403, 348]]<|/det|> P is moved to point Y in the circuit. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 359, 468, 378]]<|/det|> What is the new reading on the voltmeter? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 388, 138, 406]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 388, 198, 406]]<|/det|> 3.0V <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 388, 311, 406]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[320, 388, 364, 406]]<|/det|> 6.0V <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[448, 388, 475, 406]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[480, 388, 527, 406]]<|/det|> 12V <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[615, 388, 641, 406]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[650, 388, 693, 406]]<|/det|> 18V <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 432, 104, 451]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 432, 920, 467]]<|/det|> The circuit diagram shows a simple circuit with a battery of electromotive force (e.m.f.) 6.0V and two bulbs each of resistance \(2.0 \Omega\). <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[277, 476, 715, 594]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 606, 517, 625]]<|/det|> Which row gives the readings on the ammeters? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 636, 479, 783]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 789, 551, 808]]<|/det|>

<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 817, 176, 836]]<|/det|>
53

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 817, 298, 836]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[311, 817, 343, 836]]<|/det|>
78

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[460, 817, 480, 836]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[490, 817, 520, 836]]<|/det|>
131

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[648, 817, 688, 836]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 71, 106, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>39</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 71, 480, 90]]<|/det|>
A sample of radioactive isotope is decaying.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 101, 465, 120]]<|/det|>
The nuclei of which atoms will decay first?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 129, 134, 147]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 128, 662, 147]]<|/det|>
It is impossible to know because radioactive decay is random.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 156, 133, 175]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 155, 677, 175]]<|/det|>
It is impossible to know unless the age of the material is known.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 183, 131, 201]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 181, 873, 200]]<|/det|>
The atoms near the centre will decay first because they are surrounded by more atoms.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 208, 133, 227]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 207, 890, 226]]<|/det|>
The atoms near the surface will decay first because the radiation can escape more easily.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 253, 107, 272]]<|/det|>
<label>40</label>

<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 562, 255, 580]]<|/det|>
20 counts/ s

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 588, 131, 607]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 588, 245, 606]]<|/det|>
